Award.AwardTitle: Mathematical Problems at the Interface between Materials Science and Biology: Polyelectrolyte gels, Devices and Physiological Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support interdisciplinary research in mathematics, condensed matter physics, continuum mechanics and biology. A main theme of the work is the study of forces in living systems. The PI will take the point of view of materials science, and analyze, first, semi-flexible, biopolymer systems. These are anisotropic polyelectrolyte gels and consist of directionally biased and electrically charged elastic networks holding fluid with ions. The project starts out woith the question how the combined elastic anisotropy (modeled as in the case of liquid crystal elastomers), electrostatic and short range Van-der-Waals interactions may explain phenomena such as the negative Poynting effect in semi-flexible polymers. The next stage of the research consists in modeling the interstitial tissue. This is a polyelectrolyte gel sustaining large, rod-like protein structures that make the network anisotropic. One main goal is the modeling of edema, in order to explain the large forces that confine the excess fluid in the interstitial tissue of patients. The mathematical problems are formulated as systems of partial differential equations stemming from mixture theory. Specifically, these consist of the time-dependent equations of liquid crystal elastomers coupled with Stokes problems for fluids, and with the Nernst-Planck equations for ions. The new research will partially follow previous work on isotropic polyelectrolyte gels by the PI and coauthors, but new mathematical and modeling tools have to be developed. These new tools will also be applied to modeling the dynamics of cancer cells on fiber tissue. The research will be collaborative, involving the PI and faculty members from mathematics, physics, bioscience and engineering, as well as industrial partners, together with postdocs and graduate and undergraduate students.

This award will support research aimed at the study of forces that hold living structures together. The PI will focus on modeling interstitial tissue that connects organs, vessels and bone. In particular, the research will try to understand the physical principles underlying the trapping of unusually large amounts of liquid in the interstitial tissue, a condition known as edema. The work, jointly carried out with researchers at the Kidney Institute of the Medical School of the University of Minnesota and with a Minneapolis biosciences company, may help motivate the search for new therapies. These models will also support research on cancer cell dynamics, with the goal of modeling biomechanical aspects of the onset of tumor nucleation. The award will support collaborative research involving faculty members from mathematics, physics, bioscience and engineering, together with undergraduate students (math, physics and biosciences), postdocs and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the reported research is to explore the transfer of some of the methods and mathematical tools that have proved successful in materials sciences to modeling biological phenomena and medical devices. Three classes of interrelated problems have been investigated:

  1. Polyelectrolyte gels

  2. Drug delivery devices

  3. Liquid crystal elastomers and biological networks.

  4. A gel is a state of matter consisting of a mixture of a solid and a fluid component. In many cases of interest, the solid has the form of a polymer network able to deform as penetrated by the fluid. Expect in special defect locations, it is not possible to distinguish between the solid and the fluid, since they form a third material, distinct from the components. In polyelectrolyte gels, the polymer network possesses charged molecular groups that may electrically interact with ionic particles in the fluid.

This description fits many types of materials as well as typical biological media (e.g., muscle tissue, inter- cellular material, cartilage, interconnective tissue, …). For instance, a medical device inserted into the body becomes a gel. Research sponsored by the award focused on deriving a mathematical model for the time evolution of gels subject to multiple interactions, including mechanical and electric, as well as other intermolecular attractive and repulsive forces. To make predictions on gel behavior, it is relevant to find out how it interacts with its environment. Part of such interactions are described in terms of permeability properties of gel surfaces. An accurate mathematical description of these interactions, as achieved in the work reported here, becomes very relevant in biology as well as in materials sciences. The model equations were tested and simulated in various physical settings and were also found to posses the required mathematical properties that are needed to make numerical simulations meaningful.

 

In early experimental work, a device to deliver drug in a rhythmic fashion was constructed and experimentally tested. The rhythmic delivery of drug to match the biological frequency of the administered hormone, makes the device appropriate to therapies involving hormone replacement or treatment of certain cancers. The device consists of a membrane separating a chamber from the environment.

The desktop experimental setup shown in the figure shows a membrane separating a chamber, cell II, from the environment (body). In its swollen state, the gel membrane is permeable to glucose that enters the chamber and breaks down into hydrogen ions, as a result of an enzyme driven reaction. The ions produced in the reaction together with the drug to be delivered leave the chamber through the membrane, with the process continuing while the membrane is open. However, the hydrogen ions react with negatively charged groups attached to the polymer network and, at some threshold concentration, they cause the membrane to collapse and become impermeable. Subsequent diffusion of hydrogen ions takes place causing the membrane, again, to swell and open. The process was modeled according to the the polyelectrolyte gel model previously developed. Tools from the theory of dynamical systems were employed to show that the membrane undergoes a robust oscillatory behavior, for a set of parameters consistent with those experimentally used. It was also found that the qualitative oscillatory behavior is analogous to that of the holding pattern of the AIDS virus.

The research suggests the need to expand the model to include the pH regulatory chemistry of the body. This will be done in follow up research. [The figure shown appears in articles by Misra and Siegel (2002), Dhanarajan, Misra and Siegel (2002); Yao, Calderer, Mori and Siegel (2017).

In the third part of the research, a model of liquid crystal elastomers was developed and analyzed. The goal of the study was to set up and analyze a set of partial differential equations governing the deformation of anisotropic networks, capable to capture the behavior of biological networks, such as those found in the interstitial tissue that connects organs. Biological networks have some liquid crystal features from the point of view that they integrate rigid, rod-like proteins that may be qualitative analogous to a nematic liquid crystal. A phase transition analysis was carried out that quantifies the mechanical behavior of different physiological entities, ranging from the highly ordered elongated fibers of the hair of the ear canal to the disk-like order in red blood cells. The analysis uncovered some mathematical features of the model that have motivated studies of formation of cavities in liquid crystal elastomers.
